alfredsnippet.snippet:
"many physical problems have resisted all attempts to discover the conceptually correct explanations. Many of the frustrated theorists have reacted by abandoning the effort to achieve conceptual validity, and are now contending that mathematical agreement between theory and observation constitutes 'experimental verification.' Obviously this is not true. Such a 'verification,' or any number of similar mathematical correlations, tell us only that the theory is mathematically correct. As has been emphasized at several points in the preceding discussion, mathematical validity does not, in any way, assure conceptual validity. It gives no indication whether the interpretation that is being given to the mathematical relations is right or wrong. The inevitable result of the currently prevailing policy is to overload physical science with theories that are mathematically correct but conceptually wrong."

- Dewey B. Larson, The Case Against the Nuclear Atom
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Mathematically Correct But Conceptually Wrong
